description:
Ehrlichia ruminantium str. Welgevonden is a species of tick-borne bacterium that belongs to the genus Ehrlichia. It is the causative agent of heartwater, a fatal disease that primarily affects ruminants such as cattle, sheep, and goats.

Ehrlichia ruminantium str. Welgevonden is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium that is transmitted by ticks of the genus Amblyomma. The Welgevonden strain was isolated from an infected goat in South Africa, and it is one of the most well-studied strains of E. ruminantium.

The bacterium infects and replicates within the endothelial cells of the host's blood vessels, leading to the development of various clinical symptoms, including fever, anorexia, respiratory distress, and neurological disorders. Heartwater can be particularly devastating in susceptible livestock populations, causing significant economic losses in affected regions.

Understanding the biology, epidemiology, and pathogenesis of Ehrlichia ruminantium str. Welgevonden is crucial for the development of effective diagnostic tools, preventive measures, and treatment strategies to combat heartwater disease in livestock.
